title: Distracting additional information when `u64` is passed to the `.pow()` method of another `u64`

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-papercut
labels.description: Diagnostic error that needs small tweaks

labels.name: D-verbose
labels.description: Too much output caused by a single piece of incorrect code

body:
### Code

```Rust
fn test() {
    let x = 2_u64.pow(1 as u64);
}
```

([Playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=0bfc9be186ab150c42dead7f5c593bbb))

### Current output

```Shell
error[E0308]: mismatched types
   --> example.rs:2:23
    |
2   |     let x = 2_u64.pow(1 as u64);
    |                   --- ^^^^^^^^ expected `u32`, found `u64`
    |                   |
    |                   arguments to this function are incorrect
    |
note: associated function defined here
   --> /home/username_censored/.rustup/toolchains/stable-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/lib/rustlib/src/rust/library/core/src/num/mod.rs:927:5
    |
927 | /     uint_impl! { u64, u64, i64, NonZeroU64, 64, 18446744073709551615, 12, "0xaa00000000006e1", "0x6e10aa",
928 | |     "0x1234567890123456", "0x5634129078563412", "0x6a2c48091e6a2c48",
929 | |     "[0x56, 0x34, 0x12, 0x90, 0x78, 0x56, 0x34, 0x12]",
930 | |     "[0x12, 0x34, 0x56, 0x78, 0x90, 0x12, 0x34, 0x56]",
931 | |     "", "", ""}
    | |_______________^
    = note: this error originates in the macro `uint_impl` (in Nightly builds, run with -Z macro-backtrace for more info)
help: you can convert a `u64` to a `u32` and panic if the converted value doesn't fit
    |
2   |     let x = 2_u64.pow((1 as u64).try_into().unwrap());
    |                       +        +++++++++++++++++++++
```


### Desired output

```Shell
error[E0308]: mismatched types
   --> example.rs:2:23
    |
2   |     let x = 2_u64.pow(1 as u64);
    |                   --- ^^^^^^^^ expected `u32`, found `u64`
    |                   |
    |                   arguments to this function are incorrect
    |
help: you can convert a `u64` to a `u32` and panic if the converted value doesn't fit
    |
2   |     let x = 2_u64.pow((1 as u64).try_into().unwrap());
    |                       +        +++++++++++++++++++++
```


### Rationale and extra context

The part about `uint_impl!` is a bit distracting and doesn't seem helpful in this case.
